I bought this microphone to use primarily for Rock Band 3, as it is the only game in the Rock Band and Guitar Hero series that will not allow you to use a headset.  After receiving the microphone in question, I plugged it into my USB port, only to find that it didn't work.  "Odd," I thought and tried a different USB port.  This one worked, and I began playing.
Now, to give a bit of backstory.  I have two televisions in my room:  an HDTV and a normal "box" television.  After getting fed up with attempting to calibrate the system correctly, I now move back and forth between the two televisions whenever I wish to play a musical rhythm game.  Obviously, for vocals, an HDTV can be used uncalibrated, as, if you know the song, you do not need to watch the notes go by, so I had had the Xbox plugged into this.  Later, when I decided to switch TVs to play my guitar, I eventually replugged in the microphone in the same USB port that I had plugged it in previously.  It didn't work.  Now frustrated, I retried every port, only to finally find one that worked, which happened to be the very first port I'd tried previously.  I later came to find that the microphone I received had a short in the wire, almost as if it were used (which is entirely possible, as I got no packaging, only a plastic wrapper around the microphone).  As for the performance itself when I actually get the thing to work, it works nicely.  It picks up on my voice fairly well, although you have to keep it at a very precise angle, or it may lose lower volumes.  There is enough cord length that I can sing at my preferred distance (although I sit very close to my televisions, so take this statement with a grain of salt).  It's not a bad mic, and I'm sure the short was just a defect on the part of my microphone.  Not bad, overall.

Works good, however is not "like a new" with a little not important defect in appearance!
Really good, and works fantastic!
Works well but the cord can be a hassle.  The cord is very long so length is not a problem in use, but can be a hassle for storage.

First of all, the product is not what is pictured. I'm a girl, but imagine if i was a guy how humiliated i would be to recieve a High School Musical usb microphone? It doesn't matter to me, but if you care what the mic looks like, it might to you. The quality is good and the durability is good. It works perfectly with my ps3 and rockband 3 game. I've had no issues with it so far, but i would've liked to know what it actually looked like.

SUMMARY
Pros:
Good quality sound
Durable
Works with ps3/rockband 3

Cons:
Not what is pictured (High School Musical usb Mic is what i was mailed )

The microphone works well and was a great replacement for my original Rock Band microphone.  My original broke and have been looking all over for a replacement.  This item was a decent priced replacement so we could continue to play.

I bought 4 of these Mic's for use playing Rock Band 3. So far, so good? While this Mic is not the best USB Mic for sound quality, I believe it to be able to handle the abuse better than the higher performing Mic's like the Logitech's. This is important in Rock Band, since the Mic doubles as a Cow Bell/Tambourine/Hand Clap in game play. In time all Mic's will fail with this kind of abuse, knowing this, I searched the web for the cheapest Mic's made for Rock Band or Guitar Hero & Amazon Delivered!

My original Rock Band mic got fried by a static discharge so i had to get a new one.  This guy fit the bill and I always had good luck with logitech products so i gave it a shot.  It does not feel as substantial as the original, but i dare say that the sound quality is a bit better than the original.  Anyway it works just fine and it was inexpensive.

This was a birthday present the rock band microphones worked really well with Beatles and guitar hero. We totally rocked out and it was really fun learning how to get better with every song. Shipping was reqular ground freight and it was fast only 3 days!!!!Highly recommend! Happy Happy Joy Joy!

Microphone works fine, although sound quality isn't great.  This was advertised as an official Rock Band microphone.  When it arrived it was an official Guitar Hero microphone.  Is it really that difficult to represent the item correctly?

well I read through all the bad reviews and noticed that all of them are by people who have the psp 3000 (well at least people say)
I have a psp 2000 and the battery practically works fine
just what I needed
I got a new TV and the WII has red/yellow/white, but the TV has green/blue/yellow so I got this cord to connect the WII to the TV.  It makes a clear picture and works fine

While the product is what it is described as, it unfortunately will give me no signal whatsoever. I believe it is a fault of the a/v cable side, as plugging that in, unplugging it, blowing on it, hissing at it, calling it names, then plugging it back in seems to make it work again. I did check and have the problem across more than one tv, so it's not the tv's fault. I have no way to determine with confidence if it is a fault of the Wii, but I doubt so, as the Wii has no problem with its standard definition cabling that it came with (why, Wii, did you not include component/hdmi cabling by default? HD isn't that rare). Ah, but it is the most inexpensive version of this cable I could find, and the picture is markedly better using this than the original cabling.
The cable does what is intended for and I am happy with it.  Not sure what else to write but there is a minimum amount of words required.  Seriously though, no problems with the cable.

I got this Item about a month ago. I have not had any problems and it works just fine, but the cables feel a little on the flimsy side. In the long run it really does not matter, and for such a cheap price I really should not complain.

This item was shipped quickly. Also so far working well. I do have 1 idea to share, it doesn't come with any type of install or information data. I believe that all products such as this should. I give it 4 stars

I purchased this HDTV cable for my Wii because I recently converted from my 26 inch tube TV to a 46 inch LCD TV, and I had noticed that the Wii wasn't looking so hot on a screen designed for HD. Upon using the cable, I noticed a change in the image. I thought it was clearer and sharper, and though still not the same as X-Box or PS3, it is good enough for me. The cable is a little short, so I can imagine this could be a problem for some. With the price I would definitely recommend purchasing this!

The video quality is fine but if you have your hdmi plugged directly into your tv and have a separate receiver for audio, the cables are way too short to fit in both, so right now if I want to use the better video signal, I have to use the tv audio. I'll try to rip open the cables to make them reach but this is really a design flaw, although many newer receivers have hdmi connectors on them, there are a lot that don't.

After few months of use cable flicker and video goes off as i watch my netflix online using component cable. Picture quality is very accurate on my LCD. I don't know if flickering is due to cable or my nitendo but some online site suggested it could be cable.

This cable did its job advertised. The improvement is not dramatic, but it is noticeable and worth it at this cost. I would probably have been disappointed if I paid full price for the Nintendo cable.
I did not have any difficulty with the size of the plugs in the back of my TV, a Vizio from Costco.

The image quality seems to be leagues better than it was before.

When I first hooked up my Wii we (my girlfriend and I) had a 27 inch Sanyo tube television.  The picture looked great because of the aspect ratio; video game systems were built around televisions like this.  We soon decided we wanted a bigger and better image and upgraded to a 37' Vizio LCD.  We were saddened to see picture quality decrease exponentially and quickly became confused as to why our Wii didn't look great on what we knew to be a much better television.  We found these cables online and after applying them noticed the picture was 100% better in quality.

Long story short:  Researched component cables, found them on Amazon for a great price. Ordered cables, arrived very quickly and they worked as described.

I've enjoyed the SSX series since inception and this one was no different.  I inherited an old Xbox from a family member and wanted a few games I'd enjoy keeping my hand-eye coordination up to.  This one is fun and challenging.

It does it's job quite well. It's not the exact same touchscreen (though they are the same shape and size with the ribbon cable in the same spot) used by Nintendo, but they do the same things. This touchscreen isn't as crystal clear as the one on Gamepad. This one has a slightly rough matte finish on it, making the image on the Gamepad look ever so slightly grainy. The effect is almost unnoticeable during play though.

Some websites say the Touchscreen and the LCD are fused. This is NOT true. They're simply held together with adhesive. I used a spudger to carefully seperate the two pieces, and was able to salvage the original adhesive for the new touch screen. Also of note, The border around the screen on the Gamepad is attached to the touchscreen via more adhesive. Try to loosen it by heating it up with something like a hairdryer, then take a spudger to seperate it from the old touchscreen, and reattach it to the new one.
There was a spec of hard something in between the black plastic bezel and screen. The screen was non touch responsive until I removed it with a plastic spudger.
Super easy install and works great
I installed this screen 4 months ago and it is working great.  I installed it myself with some difficulty, not for someone who is a beginner.

Great value for the price, it fits, works and looks perfectly. i am giving 4 stars because it feels a little bit rough when you slide your finger. I guess i have to buy a screen protector so it can feel smoother.

While not an OEM replacement, this screen works well as a replacement to the game pad screen for the Wii U. Be sure your digitizer is working properly before ordering though as there are other offerings on Amazon that include the digitizer and this does not. Also, a tri-wing screwdriver may be required to disassemble the game pad. While some have received a tri-wing with their order of this screen, I did not.

Anyone who has ever played a flight sim can tell this is not like A10-warthog just by reading the info on the game. This is an arcade type game with some sim stuff add to make it sell more and be kind of fun and fast to play. Sometimes we all just want to blow the (blank) out of things and unwind. This is fairly well made and the graphics are ok for what it is(a game).
If you want a real flight sim this is not it. If you just want to get online and have some fun with others for a while this is it. The target aircraft can do hard right and left turns that would take the wings of any aircraft and thats not right but this is a game and not a sim. This was made sometime ago and graphics have come along way but it is ok for it's time.
You will not have any issues installing this or running this game on most systems with a gtx460 or better. You can max out all setting with one evga gtx560ti 2gb video card. The install dose take some time to get done and it will update for you when you run the sim the first time. This all takes 30min or so counting the install of the game.
It is what it is and thats a game not a flight sim but it is fun to play a few hours now and then.
I have a solid system and have had no issues running this at all.
If you are looking for a real flight sim that has ture reallistic flight of the aircraft and working cockpits, this is not for you. Try A10-warthog or wings over europe or wings over vietnam or IL-2. These are flight sims and run well on any solid sysetm with xp or windows 7 running.
This is a nice little arcade game with good graphics and some good chatter. It's fun to play with after spending time with DCS Blackshark.  It's a good shootem up. enjoyable!
This game was more than I expected it to be. The landings in game have added a lot to the challenge of the game.

For all those who have written bad reviews and/or who have had problems making this adapter respond 100% to your N64 controller (or the PS controllers), you have to calibrate the controller under the gaming controllers option when you go to your Control Panel directory.

If your controller does not work still even after you calibrate, then most likely it's either your controller being too old or for some reason just won't function.  The adapter itself works fine.

First and foremost this product does work with Vista no problem. I plugged it in and it was immediately recognized and started working. There was nothing I had to setup or fool around with. I am using this with an emulator to play Goldeneye and it works great. It does seem to made cheaply but it gets the job done and performs as intended. I recommend that you place this somewhere where you won't accidentally trip over the cord and break the unit though. I have mine plugged in the top USB port on my computer and have the unit velcroed to the inside of my computer desk so It's not dangling around. All in all this is a good product that works as advertised with no drivers to download (at least for Vista) and was well worth the $20.

I was a little worried because of the whole compatability issue, but it seems to work pretty well so far. I think some of the slowness is more the emulator, or my computer rather than the adapter. Its pretty sweet but it took some time to get my setting right...

over all, its worth the money.
if you love using emulators and playing old classics anytime you please without worrying if the console or the game still work, then you have to get this adapter and enjoy/relive good times playing

This adapter works fine running Windows 7.

However, be aware: It requires quite a bit of finagling to get running, and you NEED (or at least I needed) a PS2 controller to configure either controller.

If your experience is similar to mine, you will not be able to stop the N64 controller's buttons from spazzing out and letting you configure it at all unless you have a PS2 controller to plug in. I also have to leave the PS2 controller plugged in while playing with the n64 controller.

Be willing to sit down and tinker around with your control settings. When I got it to work with pj64 (sorry, can't speak for any other programs), I configured the PS2 controller first with the default Jabo plugin, then switched it over and configured the n64 controller using N-Rage. If you have a basic/good working knowledge of emulators and controller configuration, you should be able to work your way through.

Once configured, she works (almost completely) like a charm. Every now and then the adapter likes to have a fit, but a simple unplug-replug fixes that.

For those wondering if you can run two controllers at the same time on this, the answer is NO. You can't use one of these adapters for multiplayer--it must be switched to EITHER n64 OR PS2. You CAN use the Mayflash adapter for multiplayer.

If you want an n64-only controller adapter, go for the Mayflash adapter (with 2 ports). I also own one of them, and really, they are MUCH easier to configure. If you also want to be able to use a PS2 controller, though, this'll do.

I may return with an update on using the PS2 controller with other games.
Hope this review helps someone out there. :)

This adapter does work, but only with one of my 4 original Nintendo 64 controllers. (Blue, not that it means anything.) The other controllers went berserk when plugged in; the computer registered random buttons being pressed and the analog stick being moved erratically every half second.

I have heard that the controller's buttons/analog stick going crazy on the computer was an issue with the voltage being too high from USB vs through the normal Nintendo 64. However, the one controller working while the others did not is strange.

I use Windows 7. You may need to calibrate via Devices and Printers, or if it works and then stops working the next time you turn on your computer, you may get some luck by unplugging and replugging in the USB end to reload it.

It functions flawlessly on the controller that works and feels like it does on the real system. I am satisfied.

it works just fine, for those who say it doesnt wrok for vista you couldn't be any more wrong. If your using project 64 and u think it doesnt work try going to options, settings , input controller plugin and change it to nrage. then go to options again, configure controler plug in, go to the tab devices, and go to game pad pull down and select to controller. if u put ur head in it u can get it to work, the sky is the limit-B.I.G.

The lack of software included was a little troublesome, but it didn't take me more than ten minutes to find working software that worked with this.
I've been using this constantly, absolutely no problems at all.
This thing does work on vista and works great.  It was packaged perfectly and received fairly quickly.  Also you have to calibrate it on vista.

When I first got this; it worked pretty well. A switch on the side changes what kind of controller you can use. I first thought this switch worked like a power button and thought a couple friends could play off the 2 slots but that was not true. The only problem Ihave with it is that I can't run in most N64 emulations; and it prevents me form playing those. It works good for other emulators though.
If you love big boats or just boats in general and love being out on sea then this is the game for you!
Ship simulator 2008 is a fun game and I recommend to anyone who is heavy into PC simulators. It requires a fair amount of patience skil with the mouse.

Pure fun over CAR games I have played.  Sailing and power boating is exciting with tons of features.
Hope it becomes a leader in the USA.

Who is a German? A German is a piece of gadgetry which does what it is expected to do. And that's what this game is. I bought this title as part of research into a novel I am working on, and I am impressed by its factual presentation

I love this simulator it is a lot of fun controlling ships and boats. I only wish the color was better, because all the water is usually grey. But, other than that you will have a great time if you love ships.
Nice game, like the fact that I can play with grandchildren far away from me.

I bought Ship Simulator for my 11 year old son who already had Flight Simulator 2002 and X-Plane.  He loves it and enjoys it more than X-Plane.  The missions are alot of fun but you will need alot of time to complete them as they are in real time. It takes a long time to load but it could be our computer. The directions are clear and easy to follow. I like the fact that even if you crash, you can keep going and not have to start over. You can purchase additional boats to download like a cruiseship but haven't tried that yet. There is plenty to do with the base product.

Ship Simulator is a decent product for a light-hearted simulation of powered ships. Using it, you can become the captain of a number of different vessels, including a supertanker, rescue vessel, various powerboats, and even the Titanic. Several world class harbors are accurately reproduced with realistic scenery and other boat traffic. The physics of powered boats are reasonably well done. A large number of missions take you from novice to expert ship driver.

There are no sailboats, alas, and the controls can be twitchy at high speeds. There is full support for keyboard, mouse, and joystick controls, and camera angles can be varied at will.
this is a really fun game, how ever the whole world is not available for exploring, other then that its really fun. i bought for a Friend  who likes boats and he loves it.

I love good simulators of all kinds. It is a great way to experience things without a lot of trouble.

From a physics and virtual reality simulation point of view, this simulator is very realistic and artfully done. While it does lack some instrumentation detail, you get more than what you pay for in this simulation. I have been to Marcelles France to work on a ship there and I found the simulated harbor in this program to be very realistic and just the way I remember it from being there. It is just what I wanted and more.

Ron in TAmpa

An excellent simulation with excellent ship models. In particular the model of the Titanic is amazing. It's very accurate and you can walk about on all the decks, the brdige, operate controls & even go inside parts of it. Everything is lovingly reproduced like the original. I've never seen another CG model of Titanic out there that comes close to it. This is a must for any simulator fan, or anyone interested in Titanic.

This Silicon controller protector is good. It's nice and thin so that the controller doesn't feel weird or bulky in your hands. But it's also a little flimsy... I definitely see it getting torn apart with my brother's constant gaming use. But so far, it's held up remarkably well.
PRETTY COOL
It was great while it lasted need to buy a new one
Really helps keep a better grip on the controller.  The only downside is that it attracts dust like crazy and is hard to keep clean.

These covers are perfectly fine. Unfortunately, they do not solve sweating issues, but it does however give you better grip when sweating. It is very comfortable and soft, with a rubbery mixed with matte finishing feel. Although it is lightweight, it is noticeably thick, providing good protection. I would recommend this product to *anyone concerned about their controller.

I had a theory that this might solve my sweating issue when playing for longer periods of time, and for a little while I thought it had.  I've concluded that it doesn't really stop the sweating, though it might make it easier to deal with since the surface is more grippy than the bare plastic of the controller.  The controller is comfortable to a certain point by itself, and I'd say this is just a different kind of comfort.  The price makes it a worthwhile experiment.
INSTANT GRIP FOR THOSE SWEATI PALMS DOING LONG GAME PLY.THE SILICONE ALSO COMES IN HANDY PLACING UR CONTORLER DOWN. PS, PERFECT MOD, FITS NICE AND SNUG.
I like it but on the inside i have to clean it cause it gets dirty, like once a month or so.
Not love but like. This rubber grip gives you alot of grip but needs to be smoothed out with a razor blade before use. I'm happy.
This is a great product for those who prefer extrA GRIP. It also saved me from having to buy a new control. Don't play with oily hand tho.
This product is very cheap but very good and useful. it helps you get a good grip on the controller and reduce sweat. the only problem is, the rim where it is stitched together has a grabby feeling.

The cover was cheap as dirt so even needed a little help it was well worth it. When I got mine the seems were terrible, so what I had to do was take a good sharp razor blade and CAREFULLY slice them off after I got it on the controller (which it fit very well). Once I did that the cover was extremely comfortable and well worth the 200 or so pennies I spent on it.
Works great!!!  Comfortable.  The only negative was that I had to cut a little bit off the area surrounding the analog sticks as it was interfering a little bit with movement of its analog stick.
This products is great but... When your hands start to sweat, the silicone starts to get slippery.  Overall I like them.
Really great!! For the price. Your able to get a good grip while playing the Xbx 360. So worth it!

I really enjoy the tactile feel. My only concern it that the surface clings when dust is a concern. The cut corners for the triggers and bumpers of the controller seem to warp out just a bit, but I'm sure they'll form over some time.

Good silicone protective for the price. Fits well on the joystick.
I extremelly recomend it, since its up to task.

I bought this because i game so much and i have started losing the grip on the controller.... This product is awesome, only thing i suggest is clean it and the controller every month or so...
I retired the controller that had this protective case.. It was a very nasty, and greasy after one year of no use....

Ordered these up on a whim and was pleasantly surprised how much more comfortable this makes gaming. Sure there is a bit of trimming (very minor) that i had to do, but for something that cost so little this was the only con i could think of.  The molding process does seem to be fairly cheap so i would assume that there is a chance a few of them may come to customers in less quality shape than mine did (which i'm sure you could have replaced for no charge through amazon if defective).  That being said, for the pocket change cost of these it may be one of the best upgrades if you suffer from Sweaty Palm Syndrome

This is not the first one of these I have had, in fact this is about my 8th. There are many different skin types and different skin makers, so you have to judge each on it's own merit. My controller skin arrived today, well ahead of expected delivery, just as described solid black and silicone. Fit is just perfect, and installation had no problems. Good comfortable smooth texture, while still providing a much better grip than on the hard slick controller plastic. I like to clean my game equipent regularly, and I always clean even new items before using. This is a great way to test the quality of the item, I cleaned the skin using isopropanal alchohol, no gumming (like you get with lower grade skins)and no color bleed onto the rag, this tells me it is definitly silicone not some rubber stuff. Once on the controller grip is good, comfort is good, feel is natural. I am very pleased with this controller skin, I have been needing to get one for my extra controller. I will definitly be ordering a few more later, a friend has a birthday coming up.

Have had this skin for almost 2 months and so far there are no signs of wear or tear which is good. Its sticky just enough to be grippy but not overly so. It protects the controller fairly well. Keeps it from getting dirty as fast especially if you have a white controller.

Overall it feels good and is comfortable even in long play periods. The only problem I have is there is annoying little piece up by the triggers on both sides. Its right in between the trigger and the bumper buttons and there is no tension on the piece so when you switch between the bumper and triggers it can sometimes flip up and your finger will catch it. Not really a deal breaker or a big deal or anything since I plan on cutting it off anyways. Plan on buy another so far after this one falls apart. Will update my review if it doesnt last long.

Purchased the cover to help with grip issues on the controller, very satisfied with the outcome. However, it does leave some open areas on the controller's edges; which is understandable, but still could have been prevented or made a better alternative. Over all with price and value, it is a buy!
Its very good. as advertise, really help improve my gaming experience. if there are some parts that doesn't fit well. A scissor can fix it in no time.

This skin looks good, has a great grip and is very comfortable for game playing but I soon found an unfortunate and irritating unexpected flaw - the silicone attracts pet hair like crazy.  We have a couple cats and if you're a pet owner as well you'll know that it's almost impossible to keep those follicles from sticking to your furniture and clothes in some way.  With that in mind, when I opened the plastic packaging and merely set the skin on my dresser to pick up the controller, it had already attracted a nice array of cat hair when I came back to put it on.  Granted it was a small amount but since the silicone is rubberized it made removing the hair a real pain as compared to the controller's regular plastic finish which doesn't seem to act as a hair magnet and can be easily wiped clean with a tissue or paper towel. It's not a deal-breaker and I'd still definitely recommend the product but for pet owners with animals that shed, be forewarned about this inconvenience.
This memory card works but i have to take it out and put it back in every time i turn the system off otherwise it won't read.

This card is huge. Basically sixteen 8 MB PS2 memory cards in one card. Had some issues saving Kingdom Hearts 2 on this card, but I basically just used one of my other 8 MB PS2 memory cards instead and copied the saved data from that card onto my 128 MB card and was just fine at saving more files after that. That's the one reason it's not 5 stars. Overall though, if you're worried this card won't work or something just make sure you got a 8 MB memory card handy. I do highly recommend getting this card. Every game I've saved on this card has worked just fine except KH2. Maybe even get 2 to back up all your saved data in case one card gets lost or destroyed. Hope this helps anyone thinking about getting this card

The memory size of the product is exponentially more then I would ever predictably need for use with my Playstation 2 games as well as a secondary data source for all of my game saves in addition to the Playstation 3 Slim which still accepts Playstation 2 Memory Card data even though it cannot play Playstation 2 games.

The only reason why I had not rated the product higher is that it requires the Playstation 2 to format the hardware to utilize it for game saves, otherwise it is a useless paperweight. Though I am sure that those who are interested or even purchasing this device would have no doubt already have acquired the necessary console for use.
I want to play ps2 games and i needed a memory card and this fits the bill just fine. It can hold many games so if you buy it you will be able to own more games

Does what it's supposed to do.
Nice to have the extra memory. Now I can store more game saves.
Satisfied with purchase.

(Watch video for demonstration on how the card works and shows how to the card reads on the PS2) One of the most amazing things is when you can, not only find new ways to bring your old consoles back to life, but go even further and find ways to STILL find more uses. Ever since the Playstation and beyond, companies have put out tons of items that help give new life to an old thing. This memory card is no exception to that rule. I have had this memory card for well over a year now and it has not failed me yet. (This is not to imply that it will last forever, you should always make backups just in case) Imagine now being able to save ALL your game saves on 1 memory card instead of having to look for spare room on an existing 8-meg memory card. Being able to hold 16x more than what a normal memory card can is pretty remarkable. Although there have been a few odd moments that make this a bit of a... well... not so much a problem as it's more of an annoyance. (One example of annoyance you will have to deal with is that certain games will "READ" your card first before it will "WRITE" to the card to save. This can take as much as 2-3 minutes before it will finally do anything, and that can cause a problem if either you are not a patient person or you suddenly get a power spike to hit while in the middle of a save where it READS before it WRITES.) Other than that, the card works on just about every game I have played (Numbering 150+ games on my PS2) Overall, all I can say is I have not had that much of a problem with it and it has kept working for well over 1 year now. Of course, like any electronic device, experiences will vary from person to person. But for the price, you can't beat it.
It does the job it was made for!!! I needed it the cheaper ones corrupt data easily and totally suck!!!!

It was really cool to have this much storage for a ps2 but unfortunately not all games will recognize it as a memory card so i just leave it in slot 2 as storage and copy the save file for the game i want to play over to slot one first.
other than that little inconveince this is a great product i will never need another memory card

When I first put it in the PS2 it was not recognized.  Thought it was junk.  Then I read a comment from someone else who had followed a suggestion to loosen the screws on the back a bit.  I did it and the PS2 now recognizes the card.  Will see how it works now.
Item was as described but more importantly, the customer service was above and beyond! Would definitely do business with them again!

How can you go wrong with obtaining a 128 Megabyte memory card for the PS2! It's exactly the same size, there is no size fitting issue, it looks and acts like a regular memory card, and has fifteen times more space for saved games then the regular 8 Meg cards!

The only problems I have encountered with this card is that some games it is not compatible with, and the game will say there is no Memory Card in the PS2, or sometimes it doesn't read it at first, so try again and it should. I've never had to try more than 2 or 3 times.

The only games I have found it wouldn't work with was "Stuntman Ignition" (possibly "Stuntman" too, but I have not played it) and I can't recall the other one, but currently I own around 100 PS2 games, and it's been fine with all but 2 or 3 games! But don't complain, just use your existing 8 meg card, or buy one from a pawn shop or somewhere for a dollar or two, and use that for those games, and the rest on this awesome card!

Known games this doesn't work with that I have found.
- Stuntman Ignition.
- Guitar Hero games. (works fine with Rock Band tho)
- Action Replay Max (cheat device can't save data to it)
You have to file down the plastic pieces infront of the contacts.. so that they match up with your ps2's contacts otherwise it just won't work.. also it boots kind of slow but for 128mb its worth it.

I was a bit suspect when I saw this card - 128 MB for 1.25 times the cost of a Sony 8 MB card?? Well, I've been using it for three months now, and it works! There is just one issue; my PS2 console has trouble creating a new game file on the card. As mentioned by another reviewer, the workaround for this is to create the new game file on a genuine Sony card, and then copy the game file to this 128 MB card. One other minor point ... the Amazon product listing PS2 Memory Card 128MB for Playstation 2 says it's "by Sony", but that is inaccurate - this is a 3rd party memory card. With Amazon Prime free 2 day shipping to boot, well worth the price IMHO.

EDIT: This _is_ actually a 128Mb card according to my PS2. However, apparently some games aren't able to see that much space. Persona 3 FES, for example, calls it an 8Mb card. Otherwise, it appears to be a good value for the money. If your games do not have difficulty with the size, then go for it. (End of edit 28 Jan 2012)

If you think the price is good for an 8mb memory card, then by all means, go ahead. Although the card and the packaging are both labeled as 128mb, unless you are more fortunate than I, you will find yourself with no more than 8mb when you insert it into the PS2. Funny that the guys at the local game store had never even heard of a 128mb card for PS2.

It arrived on time and without delay. The card works right out of the package. It does give me some problems with the PS2 not recognizing that the card is in the memory card slot but I think that's more of the system just being old. Other than the minor PS2 errors it works fine.

I REALLY like not having to manage what and how much I put on my memory cards, and this one is like.... sixteen memory cards in one. I use my old 16 MB one as backup. My friends get all jealous when they find out that I have a frikkin 128 MB MEMORY CARD YESSS <333

The only problem is that sometimes my PS2 doesn't read it. I'm wondering if this is because it's WAAAY beyond the typical 8MB, because it always reads my 16MB one perfectly. It's always fixable by simply taking the 128 out and putting it back in, but sometimes it's troublesome if I just got comfy.

But that might just be my PS2.
EVEN IF THAT ERROR WAS FOR EVERYONE I'D STILL HIGHLY RECOMMEND THAT PEOPLE BUY IT!!

What is plug-and-play anymore? The card does in-fact hold 128mb of data, however to use the card i first have to Turn on my ps2 with the card out. Then i put the card in and check to see if the ps2 recognized the card. Then i have to hit the reset button, and yes im using mcboot ;). Id it wasn't for the non-recognition without an extra step this product would receive 5 Stars.

It's a great product, it does what it says...except you have to do some weird preparations before it's ready for regular use. When I first bought it, I thought I'd been duped; the games didn't recognize it, the system didn't recognize it, GameShark saw it as an unwritable 64MB memory card. What I ended up figuring out, is that Gran Turismo 3 has a memory manager in there, and once you move a working save file onto the memory card, the games and system magically start working! So after that bit of work, totally worth the buy for its size and the convenience that comes with that [ never have to use another memory card again! =) ].

Thanks for the person who suggested to loosen the screws on the back of the item.  I, too, had trouble with the card - I certainly was thinking twice about buying.  But what were the chances?  Games would take forever to load and would often not find the required data, but would eventually when prompted several times.  I took the suggestion of unscrewing the screws a little bit on the back of the card and have had no trouble so far.  For those who have reviewed it negatively, give that a try!

Most people don't relize that these cards
are massed produced,and put together tight.
The two very small phillips screw at the
backside just need to be loosen up in most
cases. just a little bit; enough so you can
hear or feel the memory board inside move.

Hope it worked for you.

take it easy,

Tony

I bought this product for my little sister so that she could exercise in the house and she loves it.  The rest of the family enjoys it too.  If you've never seen the XBOX or Playstation version of DDR, then this game is fine.  I gave it four stars because some of the graphics in the background are a little annoying and make it more difficult to see the arrows.

Here's the deal with this item: it's fine for little girls (and I suppose, little boys that are inclined to dance) who haven't been exposed to a better dance game.  I got this for Christmas for my 5 year old daughter; she takes dance, likes dancing, has never had or known about another 'Dance Dance Revolution' game, and she LOVES IT.  It's a big hit; she's jumping all over the place, adds up her score at the end of each song, and it's been a great, cheap gift, with exercise to boot.

No, it's not sophisticated.  Older kids or teens (not to mention adults) would grimace in pain over the ancient graphics and lousy sound.  For them, get one that goes in their PlayStation or whatever.

However, many 5 year old girls don't have a PlayStation, or need one.  This is perfect for them.  For $[...] and shipping, it worked out great for a little kid.  For a teen, it's $[...] wasted.  That's the difference.

It has a vintage video game feel to it... I happen to be a big fan of the early computer graphics Like atari and Nintendo... So I like this game... I also have stepmania and just ordered dance praise.. But I find myself going back to this one more than stepmania.

I'm an adult and I was looking for a DDR that I could use for exercise and I don't have or want an entire video game system like PlayStation or XBox.  So I figured I'd try this.  The price was right.  (Shipping charges were a bit high, though.  But it arrived two days after I ordered it, which was great.)  I didn't find one on any other site that was less than this one after you calculated in shipping charges.

Yes, the graphics and the sound quality leave a bit to be desired.  But it works just fine for what I was looking for.  The first 25 tracks or so are strange versions of songs that I have a hard time recognizing, but the later tracks that include three different unlabeled songs are much easier on the ears and also easier to dance to.  You can actually recognize the tune, hear the beat and understand when you're supposed to make a step.  There are also a couple of arcade games - Whack a Mole and a lame pinball game.  I can't figure out how to back out or exit the pinball game without powering down the entire system, though.  So I recommend avoiding that track.

I think it will work just fine for what I want - a good workout that's also fun.  I worked up quite a sweat my first time out.

Our whole family loves it.  We have an 8 & 10 yr old, the 4 of us all have so much fun together playing. Plus you have the added benefit of moving around and getting exercise.  Definitely a great addition to our home!

great exercise for the kids, instead of being braindead in front of the computer!!! pad moves around a little on the carpet, a little difficult for the under 8 population; would recommend for people without a system like play station,etc.

I was a little bit hesitant about buying this product after I read the reviews but since it was offered at a huge discount rate on Amazon I figured I had nothing to lose.  I purchase this for my 10 year old niece and when she got it, she was able to hook it up by herself and use it with a friend.  She loved it (enough said).
Stood the test of time
keeps older games working on newer TV's
Works great and comes in a timely manner. Reason why I didn't give 5 stars is cause plastic feels very cheap but for the price what do you expect.
Easy to set up. Works perfectly. But cheaply made.
looks cheap and trashy but works very well for what it is intended for.
it look a long time to get it but its worth it i have 3 items hooked up to it works perfect its small so it fits on a shelf and don't take up much room

Only one composite video input port on my ancient TV works, and I have two decks to connect to it;  a BD/DVD deck and an aging VHS VCR.  With this switch, there are 3 of three RCA inputs selectable to one output, so I have room for expansion if I happen to pick up a game console or whatever later.  The RCA jacks use standard color codes, yellow for video, white for left channel audio, red for right channel audio. For a $6 item, I thought it might be cheaply made as well, but I was pleasantly surprised with the quality of the unit.
They work well, easy to change between one devise and another. It may be old technology but if you're looking for a good RCA devise, this is it.
Great idea for a kids room or game room.  Bought it thinking I was going to need it but realized that I just needed another t.v. Instead.  Nice idea though, and cheap enough for an impulse buy.
I've had this item for at least two years now and it's still working with no problems. It allows us to have our gaming consoles available for easy use with just a slide of the switch.

This is just what I needed.  I have a wii system, PS2, and HDTV.  I plug all three of these devices into this unit.  I then plug the output of this unit into my surround sound system.  Then, depending on what device I am using or if I'm just watching tv and it plays in surround sound.  I used to be only able to plug one device into the surround sound at a time.  The ONLY reason I gave this 4 of 5 stars instead of 5 is because it just looks and feels "cheap".  As of right now, I haven't had any problems with it but I am a little worried that some of the connections my get loose.  But at this price it's WELL worth it if you're looking for something to do what I've done.

Product works very well for the price paid and I consider it a good value.  We bought a new tv with only one RCA and had a dvd player and a WII which we wanted to plug in.  Did not seem to bother wii or regular dvd player as far as speed or quality of picture.

The product is made of cheap and flimsy plastic, and for me the A/V cable it came with did not work at all, but I got my own cord and it works fine. Even with the new cord it was a fraction of the cost of the exact same item at my local Target.

I have a Wii, VCR, and DVD player hooked up to it. All work.
It looks a bit fragile, but this device meets its goal. It's really simple and works perfectly. And the price is really low. I recomend it.
Glad we bought 2 at once. Do not expect the switch to last very long. It is made very cheap. But IT WORKS!

The product does not match the image on the Amazon posting.  As other reviewers have described it is a big yellow sliding switch which will change the input.

That said... the product is the cheapest you will find and it works just fine.  I hooked it up for my grandparents and they haven't had any problems with it.

It's cheap, light, and does it's job well.

The only recommendation I have to the manufacturers is that they need to make the nob(to switch from one device to another) move more dramatically. Currently the nob slight moves to the left, to the center, and to the right. So, from a design point of view, the consumers would enjoy the product more if the nob slid all the way to each side, a bit more dramatically.

Overall: Good product.

I received this item on the 29th of may and must say thats pretty fast considering I order it on saturday and monday was memorial day and got it tuesday. What I have to say my first impresson was when I got this selector box was that its cheap quality, the thing weighed only as much as an feather and the plastic feels as thin as paper; further more when I plugged in my rca cables the sockets kinda pushed inside the casing a little bit. The good news is that it works, I tested my xbox 360 by plugging the rca cables into the box and then after that plugged it directly into the tvs rca to see if quality of picture and graphics are affected and there was no diffrence and I also had my retron nes top loader plugged in the other box sockets and the switch works. Overall its great deal considering how much it is and is amazon prime elgible.

The product does exactly what I would expect it to, and it does feel a bit cheap, but what do you expect for $6?  Mine had a problem where the video from Input 2 was not passing through.  I took it apart and saw the pin for that connector missed the soldering hole, something that should never get past quality assurance.  Fortunately it will be easier to fix than deal with the hassles of returns/etc.  Some people commented that the switch was really cheap and didn't click nicely between the inputs, I didn't find that to be the case, the switch seems solid and it locks into position nicely.

For the price, product does what it promises. The switch can be a little tricky to set on the correct slot. Still, a great bargain for putting 3 video & audio sources into 1 stereo and a projector input.

The product is pretty small, about the size of my hand, and it is cheaply made. HOWEVER... it does the job and it works great! It just isn't the prettiest looking product out here. Mine is hidden to where people don't see it anyways so looks don't matter to me, the product works just fine!
I purchased this on sale for less than a couple dollars.  It is simple and functional.  No issues with it and I would buy another one if I needed it.

This thing feels and looks really cheap. So if you're using this things for your nice/expensive entertainment set up, I would try to find a way to hide this away some where. Also, the RCA cable that comes with it is extremely short! That being said, this device does exactly what it's supposed to do. So if you need a cheap solution to having to constantly switch RCA inputs, get this. If you don't care about how aesthetically displeasing it is, then it's even more of a bonus! Would be a 5 star product if it wasn't made out of such cheap plastic, and if the RCA cable it came with wasn't so short.
If you are looking for a good looking piece of hardware this is not it... but it functions properly. Can't beat the price.
Kind of fragile, but works great and you can't beat the price.  Nothing broke, but I felt like if I pushed the cables on too hard it would break.  Cheaper than Wal-Mart even after shipping.
Works as discribed and was easy to hook up. Even though it was promoted for game players, it works fine for switching between my Roku, VCR and DVD player

Not very convincingly constructed; I feel that just inserting RCA cables or toggling the switch could break the board inside. Cables stick out at awkward angles from the body. However, for how much it cost it is certainly worth it as a simple solution, if only a temporary one.
It is just a switch so not too exciting but the quality if reasonable for the very low price.  I would buy it again.
This product seems to work for its purpose. I do not like the design because it is hard to hide the cords, but again, it works great!

This is a decent little A/V switcher for the money, with a few caveats. The build quality is certainly not high. I was afraid I was going to break the board inside when I connected the cables. However, once everything was connected everything worked very smoothly.

I can't give too much credit to the design. It's really quite terrible. The majority of the cables shoot out at angles toward the front, resulting in a mess of cables from all directions.

Overall though, this isn't an expensive little switcher and it does what it's supposed to do. I'd recommend it if you find yourself needing one and aren't concerned about it lasting a long time.

it does what its designed for and does it well for those old school wired controllers. no trip zone here.

it is a good product its not 6ft like it says we measured it but it is a little over 5ft which is good enough for our use

Upon receiving my GBM charger, I immediately snapped the cable in half upon opening the package. Thankfully, this was easy to fix with just a little electrical tape and an exacto-knife. If any of you have the same problem, the repair process is easy. Simply cut back a bit of the outer wiring on the side without a red or black wire hanging out CAREFULLY. Once done, move one set of color wires out of the way and carefully place the other color, making sure they connect, on a small piece of electrical tape. Gently fold the tape over and PUSH down hard on the now covered wiring. Do the same with the other wires, making sure to keep them within their tape and away from the other color's. Once both are securely inside, Wrap up the snapped pieces in a third piece of tape to ensure they stay snug. THIS IS NOT A PERMANENT solution. In doing this, the cable should be cared for gently, due to it's fragile reconstruction. A more permanent solution would to be to solder the wires back together, and tape them up.

Back in 1993, a little game called Myst appeared. Everyone went crazy for  it -- it featured amazing graphics, addicting search and explore gameplay,  and it was actually educational. A main part of the game was reading, so it  figures that many parents were so supportive of it. It was also, though,  terribly spooky at times. You could be anywhere in the world of Myst and  still feel a general sense of... well, spookiness.
But Myst was in 1993  -- and even though it held well throughout several years (which is  amazingly good), it started to be noticed more as a classic than current  technology.
So how well can "Riven: The Sequel To Myst" hold up  against "current technology" and the original classic? By simply  making the adventure more intresting, more long, and with more  "spookiness" -- an original Myst-cliche that adds drama to the  game.
"Riven" is even more rewarding than "Myst" so  much to the fact that it is sometimes speechless. There's five CDs to the  game -- that's clearly enough for anyone to buy this game. Even as it  starts out, you better look for clues. The developers made it so that if  you do not look for enough information, you could go from one disc to  another in less than 20 minutes.
The graphics, while nice, aren't the  best in the world. Even the control (using the Playstation controller) is  sometimes sticky. But believe me, you'll get used to it.
It's definetly  worth a buy from any fans of the "Myst" era.
Games a bit slow, music/sound effect was great, but the animation was X-cellent!!!:)  Psylocke is the best character of them all!!!:)

Marvel Superheroes was another game that came out of the post-Street Fighter 2 blaze of glory days from Capcom.  It came out near the same time as the Darkstalkers series and the Street Fighter Alpha series, and not surprisingly, there are a number of similarities between all those games, especially in terms of graphics.

This game plays like a slightly hyper version of Street Fighter with a few twists.  The wahoo-super jumps allowed to you go a good 50 scale feet up in the air and do all kinds of stuff while up there, and the super moves were similar to those in Street Fighter Alpha, although graphically more flashy.  The game came included with a number of "gems" you could collect and activate during the game for minor bonuses.

The fun part, though, was simply being able to pick Marvel characters (as they appeared in the mid-90s anyway; as they kept using those sprites for years and years they started looking more and more dated) in a good fighting game.

The game comes with a few unfortunate minor nitpicks.  1) A the follow-up to X-men: Children of the Atom, the roster was surprisingly sparse.  Only four characters return from X-men, two characters are bosses (Dr. Doom and Thanos), two characters are really quite obscure (Blackheart and Shuma-Gorath) and that means that really only a handful of new characters are added to the game: Spider-man, Hulk, Captain America and Iron Man.  A broader selection of characters would have been nice.  If we had all the Marvel characters that were later to feature in Marvel vs. Capcom 2, that would have been *WONDERFUL*.  2) The Playstation struggles with ports of these types of games, really.  This one isn't bad, but there are some notable slowdowns while playing.  Some animation frames are missing too, but you've gotta be looking pretty hard to spot those, for the most part.

This is a great beat-em-up with a fun twist on the usual engine; this being that your new super-powers and infinity gems!

The characters are selected from the most fighter-friendly gallery of Marvel, this including the little mentioned Blackheart, and the overly mentioned Spider-Man.

Also fun, is that in this game you can fly (certain characters) or at least jump high enough to make your enemies dizzy. Infact, ariel combat is probably the best part of this game; especially after watching movies like Hero or Advent Children.

The characters are suprisingly well-balanced, and fun (even Captain America, whom I'm going to hack to become "Comrade Canada" at some point, once he no longer amuses me...) And the gameplay is a good precurser to the Smash-Bros style fighter.

Infact, the game reminds me a lot of Smash Bros.

Infact, if you could throw people off-screen, I'd say it WAS Smash Bros, with Marvel chars.

Hmm.

Until next time:

Justice Prevaiils!
i've played all the capcom maevel games and this is the best the hulk is actually green .not pink or grey but green like he is suposed to be.the rounds go fast

Don't you remember the times about 7 or so years ago before the vs. games like X-Men Vs. Street Fighter or Marvel Super Heroes Vs. Street Fighter were out, when you were at your local mall's arcade room, and you spent so much time and needed money on this one game everyone was lining up to play, you kept winning and no one could beat you, you had a blast and you ruled the arcade, you used the Amazing Spider-Man, or Good Ol' Stars and Stripes himself, Captain America, and maybe a little Incredible Hulk was throw in just to show off your skills with multiple players, and you used the Infamouse Yellow, Blue, Green, and all other Gems you could get your hands on to build Speed, Strength, Power, Defence and pretty much eveything else with your character! Well I do, and I was so stoked when it came out, and now you can bring those great feelings back with the PSX Version of this classic fighter from Capcom!

Gameplay: Almost arcade perfect with minimal slowdowns, barely noticeable, and you can still pull off everything in here that was possible in the arcade version.

Sound: Perfect, unmuffled voices that match perfectly to all characters, and music is still here(and still rules)with no remixes(Thank God)! Music plays just like you would hear it in the arcade!

Graphics: Great considering the Ram limitations of the PSX(like that was a problem for this game in the 1st place), and they were done with POLYGONS, yes, POLYGONS!

Characters: You get a line up of the following characters:
1. Spider-Man (My favorite! "Maximum Spider!")

2. Captain America ("Justice Will Prevail")

3. The Incredible Hulk (What's to say, he's a "Monster" hahahahahaha...sorry.)

4. Magneto (He rules and can pull off great combos!)

5. Wolverine (The cheap one)

6. Juggernaut (He's huge and probably deals more damage than anyone!)

7. Iron Man (With the Infamouse "Proton Cannon!")

8. Blackheart (A good and Cheep caharacter, but not as much as Wolvie.)

9. Psylocke (One of my favorite X-men, and overall choice over Wolvie, to bad Gambit wasn't included.)

10. Shuma-Gorath (Not used by me, but still deals damage needed to prevail in this game.)

Over-All: If I could, a 9.3/10.0, but I can't, so 4 out of 5, the reason being, could have been one point better if it weren't for the PSX limitations, but man, that definetly didn't stop me from getting it AT ALL! GET IT IF YOU DON'T HAVE IT!!

Thank's to Amazon.com for posting this review and YOU for reading it!

I played this a long time ago back in the year 2000 with my cousin. I thought It was not a very big deal, but it whent from not-so-interesting, to very fun and challenging (at least for the kiddies). A good game for the young RPG begginer, and fan of the MEGA MAN series.

Finally, after YEARS of seeing Mega Man in 2D shooter side-scroller gameplay, Capcom began to realize the video game scene was changing, and realism was becoming more important than ever.  So in 1997 Capcom decided to take the classic gameplay of the old Mega Man games and bring Mega Man to an ENTIRE new 3D world.  I finally got to experience the 3D Mega Man adventure a few days ago, in July 2006.  So it took me NINE years to finally play it!  What can I say?  I'm slow!

I have a few problems with certain parts of the game but overall, I'm happy to report that the jump to 3D was a good one (not to mention a NECESSARY one!)  Mega Man spends the entire time in Legends jumping and shooting through a unique 3D environment.

I'm surprised so many people hate the graphics in the game.  They're quite wonderful if you ask me.  Sure, the graphics may be dated because the game is nearly 10 years old (and walking around in Mega Man Legends is sort of like walking around in a giant land of legos) but none of that should matter because you have to take into account the amount of FUN a game provides.  Mega Man Legends provides a LOT of fun.

I really loved one of the very first boss fights in the game where I had to keep running and hiding behind buildings because these giant walking blue, red and yellow machines were throwing bombs and shooting laser beams at me.  The first time I completed this battle it took a good 30 minutes ONLY for a bigger, badder machine to come in and defeat me in seconds.  At first I was angry because the game wouldn't let me SAVE before fighting this fourth boss.  "A half hour of work flushed down the toilet" was the thought that went through my head.

That led me to think the game might be too hard for me to handle, but it turned out I just didn't have the right upgrades for my X-buster equipped (actually I didn't have ANYTHING equipped!) so when I went back to do the battle again I defeated him (her, actually) rather easily.

Most of the enemies throughout the game are rather easy to defeat (including the boss fights).  Many of the boss fights will keep you on your toes, though.  The strategy to defeating many of them is to KEEP RUNNING and only turn around when the moment is right and BLAST them!  The only boss who isn't easy is the very last boss (who sounds like Michael Jackson) because he has TWO forms.  The first form you can figure out with practice, but on the second form he turns into a giant machine and THEN the challenge increases.  But it's possible to find enough money to carry up to 10 Sub-tanks to help you out DRASTICALLY.  If you were to carry 10 Sub-tanks he would be a VERY easy boss!  Despite that, the game provides a nice challenge because the way the story unfolds forces you to do a LOT of things.  You have to go HERE, you have to go THERE!  You have to collect THIS, you have to collect THAT!  You'll find out just how many items and weapons are in the game when you hit the Start button and see everything in your inventory.  It's borderline INSANE.

You see, to help make the game easier, what you have to do is go around searching for things (things located in treasure chests or holes in walls) and then you have to bring the things you collect back to this yellow vehicle where your female friend (or sister, I forget who she is) will be inside.  She can find ways to turn many of the things you collect into important weapons for you to use.  She must be smart!

I think I explained myself correctly, there.  It's kind of confusing because there's so many things you have to collect and that's the main reason I can't give the game a perfect 5-star rating.  TOO MUCH!  In Mega Man Legends you will find SO many weapons and SO many upgrades that it can easily confuse someone (like me) who's normally not exposed to this much activity in a video game.

You have to find a little dancing monkey to save your game.  When you're lost, he can also help you by telling you where to go, unfortunately many times he doesn't provide enough information.  So you can be left wandering around for hours until you finally have no choice but to find a strategy guide on the internet to help you out.

The music in the game is nice.  It's usually played quietly which is odd because most Mega Man music is RIGHT in your face.  If you can actually hear the music, it's pretty much what you'd expect from a Mega Man game.

Listen to those sound effects!!  Sound familiar?  Think South Park!  One of the children (or "pirates") sounds JUST like Butters, and a newswoman who appears later in the game sounds like Kyle's mom!  Some of the animation looks like South Park, too.  When did South Park come out?  1997?  Hmmm, makes you wonder...

Once again, the graphics.  They aren't as bad as I thought they'd be.  Sort of blocky, of course (since this IS Playstation ONE we're talking about here) but I can't bring myself to really hate the graphics because there's a certain mysterious charm about them.  Mega Man Legends LOOKS like a children's game but it's not, really.  Most children wouldn't be able to complete the game because some boss strategies require careful timing and it would be difficult for a child.

The play control... goodness.  It's definitely not easy to figure out at first.  To make Mega Man walk straight, you have to hold down the L and R buttons (this rotates the direction Mega Man is facing) while at the same time you have to use the up, down, left and right buttons to make Mega Man walk forward.  So, because you have to do a lot of running in Mega Man Legends, when an enemy is chasing you and RIGHT behind you, you have to turn around, use the L and R buttons to face him, and THEN hit him.  In the middle of hitting the L and R buttons will probably be the time you take the most hits.  It may take a few hours to properly pull off but you *should* become better at it with practice.

A trick to help you: when an enemy is chasing you, run as far away from him as possible and THEN turn around.  Usually the enemy will be far enough away that you will have time to control Mega Man so he's facing the enemy directly.  Then, simply wait for the enemy to get close and fire away!  I wouldn't blame you if you couldn't figure out the controls- it's not the greatest way to control a character.  I'm not sure if Capcom improved the play control in Mega Man Legends 2.

I find it funny and insulting that when you find a hole in a wall, many times a *very* small amount of money will be located there.  Small enough to not be able to afford ANYTHING.  It's funny because Capcom made it like "wow, you found money!" only to insult you with sofa cushion money.  To find a LOT of money you have to run around shooting enemies.

Just running around shooting enemies and collecting zenny (money) is a lot of fun, not to mention addicting.  A pretty good game worth picking up.

Its a pretty fun game, and you can spend days running through the levels to see what happens next. It takes place in a diffrent reality than regular Megaman games. However thats not a bad thing. You mostly run through Labrinths collecting Money called zenny and fight a buch of pirates. If you buy a MM Legends game get this one, it's the best by far.

To me, Mega Man Legends is one of those games you'll remember years after playing it. The game itself doesn't break any new ground and has its share of flaws, but the overall experience is definitely rewarding.

Mega Man Legends pretty much plays like the earlier Tomb Raider games control wise. Unfortunately, there are a few problems with the control scheme, such as a lock on system that doesn't allow you to move while locked on an enemy (which was fixed in MML2), and the fact you also must contend with moving the camera manually in order to compensate for the lack of a better lock on system to hit your mark.

Legends also uses a pretty similar graphic engine as Tomb Raider as well, complete with all the flat, 2D scenery that rotates with the camera and all the pixilated surfaces and clipping problems that accompanied that era of Playstation gaming. Unlike Tomb Raider, the environments in Mega Man Legends are much brighter and colorful, adding to the games cartoon-like feel, rather than the dark, dank death-trap ridden tombs that Lara Croft raids.

The pretty low difficulty level of the game is also an important factor to look at as well. Considering this game is somewhat geared towards an younger audience, this isn't an error so to speak, but older, more experienced players will fly through the game in a handful of hours (especially considering most of the game bosses can be defeated by constantly circling around them and firing). Thankfully, Capcom added an unlockable difficulty setting to make the game harder for those looking for an additional challenge (oh and is it ever a challenge). Add to this Capcom increased the difficulty on Mega Man Legends 2 a few notches, and all can be forgiven here.

So with all these problems, why is Legends such a good game? Heart, and lots of it. Mix in a good story, a wonderful cast of characters (and enemies), and throw in some of Capcom's more respectable forays in voice acting department, and you got a winner. While some may claim that Legends carries a "kiddy tone", I actually find this to be one of the game's charms and strengths. Honestly, if you don't laugh when one of the Lego Men, err, I mean Servebots messes up and angers Tron, there is something wrong. Seriously, it isn't anymore kiddy than a Mario or Zelda game (or most of Nintendo's gaming library for that matter).

The other thing that makes the Legends series so great is the fact Capcom decided to quit while they were ahead. While I myself still wish they would churn out a Mega Man Legends 3 (considering some of the unresolved issues in Mega Man Legends 2's ending), at least Capcom didn't make a zillion sequels and drain the series of all it's fun and respectability, of which they have done a fine job of doing to the original series and X series.

In the end, Mega Man Legends is not a game you'll remember for amazing graphics, razor-sharp control, or challenging quests. Instead, you'll walk away with a overall memorable experience.

For the "Ace combat" initiated, this game is a lot better that the original "Ace Combat" for it's graphics and play, although I have to say how much I enjoyed "Ace Combat" too, in the beginning. Not only have the grapics been improved but the game now includes a scannar that actually tellls you which way the enemy planes are pointing - a must for the correct deployment of missiles. Missions are plentiful and, in addition to the possibility to select a wingman (or, indeed wing"woman" as sexual equality aware NAMCO has included) you can even direct him or her to take on a certain part of the mission, or do the mission without support, as you wish. There are the usual night missions and canyon-runs, and plenty of planes to choose from. Game action is very smooth too. The planes available in the more advanced stages of the missions are great. An enjoyable game!

I've played nearly EVERY ace combat game, and this one ranks up there with Ace combat 4 and 5.  This one is a HUGE improvement over the first one (titled "Air combat").  The story isn't as good as the playstation 2 versions (4, 5, and Zero) but the gameplay is great , especially if you have a dual-analog controller.  I give this game a 8.5/10

works well for me, except i can't get my championships to show at the end. Im not sure if that is a glitch or not.

While the game may be outdated and not as fun to play as some of the more recent titles, I can't fault this game because this is where it all started.

On its own merit in 1995, it was a smash-box hit and everybody was ahhed by the graphics, 3d environments, and the musical score. Back then, we were used to Super Mario World and Final Fight. This was something completely different. No one cared about the flaws the game had back then. It was par for the course.

Now, in 2012, a whole 17 years later (really? that long ago...), a person can easily recognize the flaws of gameplay, sound, and playability. Sound effects are lo-fi, almost like comparing a cassette to a CD. The soundtrack is still amazing though, as if it were mapped on an entirely different bit format. Playability, there is one overall mode - the 1P Arcade mode (unless you count options and 2P). Every successful completion of the game with a character unlocks a new character to choose - the same one you fight in round 8. After that, you have all of the characters and there's not much else to do. There's no team battle, no survival, just...1P Arcade. So it works for 1995. The ending movies are pretty bad, all having the same soundtrack and really blocky ugly CGI. Of course in retrospect, this WAS 1995.

The movies never got better in the series until much later, but they did improve some.

Overall, Tekken deserves a place in your PSX collection, right next to 2 and 3. You won't play it often because Tekken 2 covers all of those bases and more. So to me, at least, this game is merely a collection piece.
Well i bought it because i wanted to collect all the tekken games(i did :D) and it brings back alot of memories

The first time I played this game I was amazed by the sheer quality coming out of this game. The grahics were absolutly incredible and the gameplay was out of this world. This was all in 1995. Now that tekken2 and tekken3 had arrived on the scene it seemed as though tekken had faded to a fairyland. Back then in junior school everyone was in conversation about all the characters and the secret ones and how you unlocked them. And know that games like tekken2, tekken3 and soulbade coming to the playstation tekken was suddenly never an issue. All I know is that tekken was a fantastic game at launch and had also beaten virtua fighter on the saturn which was a rival to tekken. If tekken had never come out then I believe with a 100% that none of the existing games that I have mentioned above and their sequals would have been in existance. Despite these games being in existance tekken is still a soulfighter and is the game that made namco famous on the playstation.

After defeating Xenogears, I was looking for a game that was fun to play, and didn't require me to do much thinking. Xenogears was a monster game that had a fantastic, yet confusing plot that really made you think. Breath of Fire 3 is a complete change of pace. Instead of going for an engrossing and confusing plot like FF7 and Xenogears, Breath of Fire 3 continues a simple, but fun plot that feels refreshing to play after finishing a monster game like Xenogears.
Breath of Fire 3 doesn't have an overly confusing story. Once long ago, there was a clan on earth known as the dragon clan. After gaining enough power to destroy the world, the dragon clan suddenly disappeared. You play as Ryu, a young boy who suffers from amnesia. He soon befriends two thieves named Rei and Teepo. After he gets into trouble with the authorities, he soon finds out he is an ancestor of the dragon clan. So he embarks on a journey to uncover his mysterious past.
Sound original? Sorry, but if it's originality that you want, you won't find it here. Even the battle system is painfully unoriginal. As you play it, it will feel like you have played something else exactly like it. The story, the battle system, everything feels like it was used many times before, and i hate to say this, but the ending is very disappointing.
However, with all gripes aside, Breath of Fire 3 is a fun and engaging quest. My favorite part of the game was the characters; they are interesting, and very funny. I also liked that the plot never once got confusing. Even though it was unoriginal, it never got off target and it even sometimes kept you on the edge of your seat.
With all the complaints aside, Breath of Fire 3 is fun game to play through. After playing through a monster game like Xenogears, it is refreshing to play. Unfortunately, don't get too excited about the ending.
If you like dragons , and magic you'll like this game .  You start out as a child grow older learn about his own race  called the Brood .
